item.content:encoded:
Russell Beattie comments on the importance of wireless application development tools designed for everyday corporate developers. Microsoft gets this, but Nokia, Motorola, Sun and most other big wireless players don't.

At my company, JumpStart Wireless, anyone who can create a spreadsheet can also create wireless applications. This spreadsheet approach to wireless applications works with any application that can be captured as a set of business forms. Once a form is described, the application is automatically generated using artificial intelligence technology. (an overview here, email me for more technical details). The form description is created by working with a customer's existing paper forms and studying how those paper forms are actually used.

I'm sure there are other simplified approaches as well. Instead of launching yet another Java framework standardization effort, the wireless software community should be actively seeking easy-to-use alternatives to Visual Basic and the .Net Compact Framework.

The tools to be developed must be much easier to use than C++ and the current complex Java programming environments. Russell makes the point that when

a slick marketing driven company like Microsoft comes in with a click-click-click demo of how easy it is to create mobile apps with their .Net toolsets, CTOs are going to sign on the bottom line.
He is absolutely right.

No matter how many GUI tools you pack around it, and how many frameworks you design, C++, is just too complicated for most programmers and certainly not suited to typical corporate applications.

Microsoft, with their initiatives around Visual Basic and .Net Compact Framework, has the right idea. Visual Basic and the approaches around it have been well designed for simple "one-off" applications. Even though that approach does not scale well and mostly does not produce reusable code, it is enormously easy to teach and use.

item.content:encoded:
Why is wireless business software important? Wireless business software is the only way on the horizon that carriers can add $50 per month in average revenue per user (ARPU). Note that this $50 ARPU is probably roughly split between the software provider and the carrier.

The key goal, and battle cry, for wireless software providers should be building applications that are worth $50 per month to a large group of subscribers. With these numbers there is a compelling business model for both the carrier and the software developer. The question is: what applications allow for this kind of ARPU?

There are millions of business users with a strong case for paying an extra $50 per month per user. These users are the field staff of businesses doing repetitive forms-based tasks like repair, sales order taking, inspection, delivery, and so on. Why are these folks a no-brainer for $50 per month? Because the right wireless applications can typically produce $1000 or more per month in value. According to various analysts there will be between 30 and 50 million such mobile workers. Nextel estimates that there are 28 million service industry potential users (US only) today. Frost and Sullivan (a wireless industry analyst) in a Nov 2003 report by Brent Iadarola estimates that the addressable US market for these wireless data applications will grow from 37 million users in 2002 to 55 million in 2006. Within this market, they estimate adoption of wireless data will grow from 2 million in 2002 to 22 million in 2006, a 145% annual growth rate. Yankee and IDC project similar market sizes and growth rates.

This is the group that kicks off wireless business software.

Even though there is much focus on other segments, I'm skeptical:


- Games and ring tones will never be worth more than a few dollars per month for the vast majority of wireless subscribers. With the volumes possible (100s of millions of consumers) maybe successful high growth startups can happen with this very low revenue per sale, but it looks to me like only specialized "hit-oriented" small companies can succeed with these products.

- Wireless email and calendaring, the most widely discussed business applications, are worth $50 per month to only a very small segment of high end managers.

- Wireless connectivity for laptops -- again only a small segment is willing to pay $50 or more per month for such access. Besides, wirelessly connecting a laptop only appeals to mobile workers willing and able to carry a laptop around with them all day. This is a very limited group compared to the people willing and able to carry a smart phone in their work.
